title: Verbal short-term memory: Primitive or parasite?
abstractText:
Remembering sequences of events temporarily over a few or tens of seconds is a key feature of most human activities, underpinning the production of language, thinking and reasoning, skilled mental performance, among others. For the last 50 years or so our understanding of short-term memory has been dominated by the idea that the brain has bespoke, relatively isolated, processing modules - so-called processing primitives - dedicated to storing information over the short-term.

This project challenges this notion and suggests instead that short-term memory is parasitic on brain systems developed mainly for processing sensory information and planning (but not always producing) gestures, of which speech production is one. In a series of eleven studies the project re-examines canonical features of short-term memory performance that have been taken as evidence for the 'primitive' view, and seeks to re-construe the findings from the 'parasitic' standpoint. One of the key goals of the work is to integrate phenomena traditionally associated with short-term memory with those associated with perception and action with a view to bringing about a fundamental shift in the way that short-term memory is understood.
